description:
Ebola is mostly portrayed as a definite death sentence, making it hard to believe that anyone could recover and survive the illness. However, as the existance of survivors demonstrate, Ebola patients have some hope of recovery. Survivors can return to a normal life after a months-long recovery that can include periods of hair loss, sensory changes, weakness, fatigue, headaches, and eye and liver inflammation*. But, how to build trust on this outcome? How to convince people that the person they have in front of them pose no risk to their health?

* What it feels like to have Ebola (interview with a survivor)

In general, there seems to be little unclear information about the recovery outcome and what happens to the organism of a surviving person. Misconceptions and stigma abound. Some publications report the following regarding Ebola survivors: men should restrain from having unprotected sex for up to 90 days and women should ask their doctors before breastfeeding their babies again or consider other feeding methods. Information like this might be the reason for comments such as (taken from this article):
  • "I am happy Dr. Korkor has returned but I am totally not convinced he is Ebola free. I will shake his hands after 21 days."
  • "I will greet him from a distance."
  • "I still haven't taken my exams while my classmates have moved on to the next level. The professors said they were going to grade me by telephone."
  • "Ebola has ruined my life even though I am cured. No one wants to spend a minute in my company for fear of being contaminated."
  • "People don't believe that I had Ebola because they can't believe I survived."
There are many misconceptions about the survivors, but with the great potential of good things that they can bring to their communities we should turn their image into a positive one.
Ebola survivors working on hospitals, like  Dauda Fullah does, can provide moral support to existing patients and facilitate the interaction between them and their doctors: He provides more than medical support. Helena Makeni, a nurse who cared for Fullah, says that he encourages the patients who are really struggling. He goes up to them and says, "Look, I've been through this, and I survived. Just do what the doctors say, and keep fighting." And they listen.
Survivors can also help to clarify misconceptions as the ones that Mohamed found:  people told him they think that being an Ebola patient means that you are dead, you will never recover, that it will kill you, no matter what you do.

What to do?:
1) Make survivors' stories easily available to the affected communities. Having access to internet, it took me quite some effort to find survivors' stories as most of the news related to Ebola are about its current spread and growth. Guess how unlikely it might be for isolated communities to learn about survivors.
2) Following the approach taken for cancer survivors, portray Ebola survivors as a celebration of life.
3) Make clear that survivors don't carry the Ebola virus in their blood and teach the community on how Ebola survivors won't get them sick. We may use printed materials (stickers on taxis? informative cards?) to spread mesages such as: "Hugging an Ebola survivor won't make you sick" or "Having dinner with a survivor can't give you Ebola".  Once someone recovers from Ebola, they can no longer spread the virus except via their semen or, possibly, breastmilk (and only for a limited time).
summary: Given Ebola's high mortality rate, surviving it might be considered a miracle. Patients who survive this terrible illness should be embraced by their communities rather than stigmatized. Using as inspiration the approach taken to portray cancer survivors we may help the communities to appreciate and embrace the value of each saved life, while showing them that, although deadly, Ebola does have some percentage of recovery outcomes.
title: Portray Ebola survivors in a positive light: "Hugging a survivor won't make you sick"
